la carte postale la carte postale est arrivée dans notre boîte aux lettres au milieu des traditionnelles cartes de voeux elle était pas signée l'auteur avait voulu rester anonyme ily avait l'opéra garnier d'un côté et de l'autre les prénoms des grands-parents de ma mère de sa tante et son oncle morts auschwitz en 1942. vingt ans plus tard j'ai décidé de savoir qui nous avait envoyé cette carte postale en explorant toutes les hypothèses qui s'ouvraient moi ce livre menée cent ans en arrière j'ai retracé le destin romanesque des rabinovitch leur fuite de russie leur voyage en lettonie puis en palestine et enfin leur oetiiteote la carte posrale 24 prix france

zztozz zztozz mr. william h. webb chief operating officer of philip morris companies inc. is pleased to announce the appointment of mr. jean- claude kunz vice president central europe to the position of president eema region effective immediately in his new role jean- claude will report to mr. andreas gembler president of philip morris jean-claude began his career with philip morris bema in 1983 as business development analyst in 1984 he was promoted to general manager eastern europe and in 1986 he was appointed general manager for the levant and parts of the middle east in 1990 he was appointed area director bastern europe and in 1992 area director central europe in 1993 he was appointed to his current position of vice president central europe jean-claude has played key role the success of eema 's acquisitions and the development of the emerging markets of central europe and the balkans with the transfer of the domestic scandinavian and finnish markets to georges diserens vice president switzerland scandinavia finland baltics duty frce will assume responsibility for central europe and ls '' appointed vice president switzerland central hans fluri vice president eastern europe will assume additional responsibility for the baltics and is appointed vice president eastern international inc. the eu europe and duty free europe and the baltics also reporting to jean-claude will be rudi schweizer senior vice president john guarino director africa and levant jacques guyot vice president operations kathleen linehan vice president corporate affairs turhan talu vice president gcc and turkey jean-michel toinet vice president marketing please join us in congratulating jean-claude and in wishing him every success in his new position as president eema region at the same time join us ie extending our best wishes to georges and bans in their new responsibilities

interoffice memorandum reymoll tobaccocompary zzsubjectzz zzsubjectzz zzsubjectzz zzsubjectzz zzsubjectzz zztozz zztozz zztozz market share study ms. r. h. steele date november 1991 tory payne zzfromzz zzfromzz zzfromzz objective to investigate the relationship between mutagenicity and weight of tobacco summary mutagenicity estimates using nonlinear regression model were obtained on sample of 24 rjr products correlations between mutagenicity estimated from linear and nonlinear regression models and weight of tobacco burned tar cigarette length and air dilution were determined preliminary regression analyses were performed to investigate burned tar cigarette length and air dilution for rjr products the relationship of the above-mentioned variables to mutagenicity conclusions tar and air dilution were the best single predictors of mutagenicity on revertants/mg tar basis tar was the best single predictor for mutagenicity on revertantslcigarette basis followed by weight of tobacco burned various combinations of weight length tar and air dilution predicted mutagenicity better than any variable by itself however variables other than these influence mutagenicity since the percent of variability explained ranged from only 48 to 82

talks with dr. carl g. baker director of the national cancer ins stitute the desirability of forming an international study group concerned with research into tobacco and health problems was discussed this letter is to invite you on behalf of your organization to participate in this the proceedings will aim at providing the relatively few active investigators in tobacco and health research programs with an opportunity to discuss freely current and future research programs with the intent of reaching common objectives more quickly will be composed of investigators primarily eheogrou in tobacco and health research oriented towards producing less harmful smoking products the partici- pan ts mus be both willing and able to share with other investigators what is being learned from their current activities and openly discuss plans for future research in the field it is thought that by bringing such group of experts toget ther to review ongoing studies and to plan future investigations jointly less harmful tobacco products will be available sooner and cos tly research projects will not be duplicated unneces- sarily the meetings would be held at yearly intervals with the different organizations acting as host informa tion and study group the

sample letter concerned citizen april 1998 the honorable office address washington d.c. zzdearzz zzdearzz zzdearzz zzdearzz zzdearzz senator or representative united states senate/or/united states house ofrepresentatives am writing to express my strong opposition to s. 1415 senator john mccain tobacco legislation as concemed citizen am offended by many aspects ofthis legislation including unfair taxes the creation of la black market and sweeping fda the mccain bill constitutes modem day prohibition the fda would have discretion under the mccain legislation to ban tobacco products immediately without any congressional action the fda is an unelected federal agency that should not be given unfettered authority de ban tobacco tobacco prohibition would foster an immediate black market and smuggling operations -creating boon for organized crime ban on tobacco products also wouid be crippling blow on many communities whose economic stability depends on the tobacco industry hundreds of thousands of people have jobs linked to the production distribution and retailing of tobacco products high cigarette taxes will cause job losses in every sector of the tobacco industry from am hard-working taxpayer and support legislation that keeps tobacco products out of the hands ofminors however strongly oppose any bill that infringes on an adult right to smoke legal product adults make up 98 percent of all smokers in the united states and they will bear the burden of the huge tax increases proposed by encourage you to vote against the mccain bill and any legislation that mirrors the devastating effects ofthe mccain bill thank you for your attention to this matter authority the seedbed to the sales counter senator mccain zzrespectfullyz zzrespectfullyzz zzrespectfullyzz

newsday new york ny may 1998 friday all editions viewpoints page a57 big tobacco cant cut teen smoking by alan brody ajlan brody marketing journalist is the author of cigarette seduction '' the tobacco industry may be guilty of many big lies but congress and the public health community may be developing big lie of their own that the cigarette companies can undo the phenomenon of teenaged smoking as stanton glantz author of `` cigarette papers wrote `` the tobacco companies know how to get kids smoking and but the issue is bigger than tobacco companics because the settlement talks with the government are based on the tobacco companies supposed omnipotence the likely failure will create whole new layer of corruption all the way from illegal sales d8 fly -by-night tobacco companies to the potential for more damaging products to enter the gap adults tend to have poor memory of their own youth and why they themselves became smokers it was n't because the tobacco companies marketed to them it was because they marketed to adults and as teenagers they desperately lively grandmother in her 80s confided to me that she started smoking at 10 and quit at 40. that means she began smoking in the 1930s when cigarette ads were still focusing on tobacco leaf qualty and turkish flavor there were no ads for teenagers and certainly none for pre-teens in fact the country barcly paid any attention to teens couventional wisdom has it that advertising and marketing are responsible for selling tobacco it helps but does it cause smoking zzquestionzz the absence of advertising finland and for while in italy showed that cigarettes sell just fine the etiology of smoking runs deeper into the realm of mystery than legislaton and public health oflicials may care to venture but that is truly where the allure has its origins teenagers are n't responding to ads nearly much as they are since we as society have taken no steps to fill gap in coming-of-age rituals common in other cultures guess what industry has come to occupy this role zzquestionzz kids seek magic path to the `` real heart '' of adulthood they will accept danger but they want belonging and kind of personal guide the mystical amulet popular bs myth cigarettes offer this that when teenagers were invited to tell congress why they smoke one girl said she was nonsmoker until she watched talk show where experts cited depression as reasons teenagers smoked `` so that 's what you do '' said the girl who have no objection to taxing the tobacco companies or throwing few perjurers in the hoosegow but the demand for smoking is phenomenon that is not covered by the proposed legislation and both the tobacco companics and the public health groups are going to be left with an embarrassing and costly predicament as the european experience has shown raising prices works for while and then kids have way of readjusting greater fear as one teenager put it in an interview with an american cancer society worker spoke with `` if you make them so expensive we 'll just go on to in this politicized environment it is easy to believe that legislation can make magic or that the tobacco companies are solely responsible for the rise in smoking when the centers for disease control announced that smoking had increased 30 percent le six years they were quite pleased because the implication la that the tobacco companies are to blame but this was also during the most hostile media period tobacco has ever faced newspapers tv networks and even magazines that once quivered at the thought of losing cigarette ad dollars noww thumb their noses knowing drug given proper economic motivation they will know how to stop kids from smoking wanted to be adults without ads responding to their own demands of adjusting to the tribulations of growing up they are about life and death only adds to their `` spirit power apparently bad been feeling depressed and she began smoking other drugs

future sense arecuon and hoge from lesders he says trom u.s. president corporale executive university dean and hesd of the local charity drive these themes have been resonating explicitly and implicitly in the presiden tial campaign both president bush and gov clinton have tried to harmess the widespread malaise among voters and offer hope for the future mr. clinton by invoking `` change at every opportunity and mr. bush by promising that his poli- cies areon the brink of yielding significant close look at several people who have seen their confidence in the future erode suggests why there is such widespread disilusionment with the american dream but not everyone is grim those who have come from the poorest backgrounds or encountered the greatest hardships seem retain the most hope `` everyone seems defeated when mark donnelly came of fagein the 1960s no problem seemed insoluble in 1962. as 20-year-oid army private mr. donnelly went te oxdford miss .. to protect james meredith whose enrollment at the university of mississippi sparked race riots for et week mr. donnelly stood outside mr. meredith 's dormitory with mifle guarding him against attack one student spat on him he recalls mr. donnelly also served in vietnam but after his discharge he marched 00 washington to oud test the war and be- came regional ganizer for vietnam vets against the war while attend- ing columbia uni- versity mr. don- nelly blocked police from entering building after stu- dents had seized it `` we were gen- eration that had hoped the world could be better mark donnelly place says mr. donnelly now 50-year old vice president at chemical bank in new york city `` we naively thought that problems were solvabie today his view is different the lems he sees the budget deficit strato- spheric health-care costs the aids epi- demic and deficient schools seem insu- perable the assumption that prosperity would cure social ills hit the wall of reality in the form of intractable urban poverty and fury that erupted in los angeles this spring the proportion of households wy annual incomes under 15,000 was lower in 1990. after adjustment for inflation than in 1980 or 1970 but it remained stubbornly close to 25 `` 've become very cynical about the ability of our system to bring about change mr. donnelly says `` there '' 's real malaise in america right now everyone seems defeated you no longer belleve anything 's going to get done though he concedes that his current imperfect voices of generation fear for the status of american dream despite their success many feel their parents had more cause for optimism yet outsiders still want in by clare ansberry and thomas f. o'boyle staff reporters af the all street journal for many americans the future seems about as secure as dandelion puff an entire generation now reaching middle age zzquestionzz ing whether they or their chidren can do better than their parents job security went out with three- piece suits and pundits have coined new term dumpies for downwardly mobile professionals today both mother and father work not to be rich but to send kids college the complicated family ssene looks more like an andy warhol canvas than norman rockwell portrait statistically americans both rich and poor are improving their lots their buying power has doubled since the 1950s and their standard of living remains the highest in the world others outside the u.s. still believe people can improve their lot in america the current wave of immi- grants is the largest since early this cen- even many americans despair about tbe future in part that 's because in relative terms america 's standard of liv- ing is n't as far ahead everyone else 's as it once was other countries are catching up nor is the u.s. rate of growth as rapid as it once was and even some affluent americans have discovered as their par ents warned that money doesa't buy hap piness the same numbers one three americans told researchers at the na- tional opinion research center they were `` very happy '' in both 1957 and 1990. no amount of money ensures happiness con- cludes david g. myers in his book `` the pursuit of happiness rather happiness satisfaction with whatever one has warren bennis business professor at the university of southern california has another expianation for this widespread and mahler-like melancholy recalling sunny phrase ol the 1930s `` the long sum- mer of the future '' he says today that feeling seems be missing `` we want economic growth tury -qoud has the wall street journal 8/11/92

philip morris inc new york new york contact dolly colby 212-878-2144 court rules key florida medicaid agency si unconstitutional severely narrows application of controversial law tallahassee fla. june 28 circuit judge in tallahassee today declared key provisions of the controversial 1994 amendments to the medicaid third-party liability act unconstitutiona and held that the state agency charged with administering the state medicaid program lb unconstitutional structured charles r. wall senior vice president and deputy general counsel for philip morris said the ruling should provide the basis for the dismissal of claim by the state of florida today 's ruling came in declaratory judgment case filed by the associated industries of florida philip morris inc. and others `` because the court ruled that the state agency is unconstitutionaly structured we believe that the claim based on the state 's third-party medicaid liability act should now be dismissed said wall that case is pending in in addition today 's ruling clarified crucial issue the state of florida sought to obscure last week in media interviews after the hearing leading to today 's ruling the court held that the new medicaid law applies only to allegedly tortious conduct occurring after july 1994 the date the new law in his ruling circuit judge f.e steinmeyer said the law `` may only be applied prospectively specifically to conduct of potential third-party defendants that occurred after the amendments effective date of july 1994. no party shall be held liable under the amendments for conduct or activities that `` this could well be the beginning of the end of this lawsuit by the state of florida wall said `` the state claims governed by the new medicaid law are essentially based on allegedly tortious acts occurring before the effective date of this law and therefore can not be the basis for any finding of liability the court also declared unconstitutional the new medicaid law 's provision that allowed the state to join together in single lawsuit hundreds or circuit court in west palm beach became effective occurred before july 1994

experiments the effects of cigarette smoking on health have been inferred from observational studies that compare persons who smoke with nonsmokers in these comparisons the disease outcomes are coresta 1982 symposium abstract form author indicate presenting author j. g. nepomuceno presenting a. g. kallianos j. e. wickham and a. e. stagg philip morris research center p. 0. box 26583 richmond virginia 23261 title of paper refinements to the ftc procedure for the baiivitinvno affiliation and address determination of tpm ni cigarette smoke study group abstract text the for lightweight and disposable filter holder assembly used in the collection of total particulate matter in cigarette smoke was developed as currently used lucite filter holder not only are these new holders lighter in weight 15 grams versus 27 grams for the lucite holder but the inconvenient and time-consuming steps of washing these holders in an alcohol ba th and drying prior to subsequent use are also eliminated during the development of these holders it was noted that certain types of materials including lucite were very sensitive to changes in the moisture content of the environment resulting in highly variable tpm results these variations become most significant for extremely low yield cigarettes where negative tpm deliveries have been frequently encountered during the analysis negative tpm result indicates loss of weight of the filter assembly the smoking procedure these negative numbers have been obtained even when during the filter pads were clearly stained by the smoke particulate phase indicating that something was collected during the smoking process therefore the apparently negative tpm deliveries must be result of an artifact in the smoke particulate ma tter collection procedure exper rimental data are presented showing tha the observed artifact is primarily due to some phenomenon occurring at the surface of the filter holder during but extraneous to the particulate ma tter collection process this phenomenon is shown to be attributable to the inherent property of certain ma terials including lucite to easily adsorb in order to minimize the observed bias in the tpm results and thus allow for the collection of more meaningful data lightweight and disposable holder made out of polypropylene and polystyrene was developed in addition to the obvious advantages of being lightweight and disposable experimental evidence delivery levels is eliminated through the use of these holders because of their inherent insensitivity to moisture fluctua ations in the environment replacement and desorb moisture from the environment was presented showing that negative bias which becomes at low tpm significant .uu 19 rs
